    Description

    ì¶”ì²œ ì‹œìŠ¤í…œì´ë€ ê°€ë ¹, ì•„ë§ˆì¡´ì—ì„œ ì œí’ˆì„ êµ¬ë§¤í•˜ë©´ ì´ ì œí’ˆì„ êµ¬ë§¤í•˜ëŠ” ê³ ê°ë“¤ì´ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ìƒí’ˆì—ë„ ê´€ì‹¬ì´ ìˆì„ ê²ƒì´ë¼ íŒë‹¨í•´ ì¶”ì²œí•´ì£¼ëŠ” ë°©ë²•ì´ë‹¤. Providing suggestions for items that are most pertinent to a particular user

    â€˜ì•„ì´í…œâ€™ì„ ê¸°ë°˜ìœ¼ë¡œ ì‚¬ìš©ìì—ê²Œ ì¶”ì²œì„ ì œê³µí•œë‹¤. Item-based recommendation systems, not user-based

    ì´ê²Œ ë¬´ìŠ¨ ë§ì¸ê³  í•˜ë‹ˆ, ì„¸ìƒ ì¸êµ¬ 80ì–µ ëª…ì„ ì „ë¶€ ì¡°ì‚¬í•˜ì—¬ ë‹¨ ëª‡ í¸ì˜ ì˜í™”ë¥¼ ê¸°í˜¸ì— ë”°ë¼ ì¶”ì²œí•´ì£¼ëŠ” ê²ƒì€ ì§€ê·¹íˆ ë¹„íš¨ìœ¨ì ì¸ ë¬¸ì œì¼ ê²ƒì´ë‹¤. It will be not effective to recommend movies after investigating huge volumne of populations

    ë”°ë¼ì„œ, ì‚¬ëŒì´ ì•„ë‹Œ ì•„ì´í…œ, ì¦‰ ì˜í™”ì™€ ê°™ì€ ì‹œê°„ì´ ì§€ë‚˜ë„ í•œê²°ê°™ì€ ê²ƒë“¤ì— ê¸°ì¤€ì„ ë‘ê³  ì¶”ì²œ ì‹œìŠ¤í…œì„ ì ìš©í•œë‹¤. Thus, we need to focus on consistent data like movies

    ê°€ë ¹, ì˜í™” â€˜íƒ€ì´íƒ€ë‹‰â€™ì„ ë³¸ ì„œë¡œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ë‘ ì‚¬ëŒì´ ë¹„ìŠ·í•œ ì¥ë¥´ì˜ ë¡œë§¨ìŠ¤ ì¥ë¥´ì˜ â€˜ì–´ë°”ì›ƒ íƒ€ì„â€™ì„ ì‹œì²­í–ˆë‹¤ë©´, ì¶”ì²œ ì‹œìŠ¤í…œì€ íƒ€ì´íƒ€ë‹‰ì„ ë³¸ ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ì‚¬ìš©ìì—ê²Œ ì–´ë°”ì›ƒ íƒ€ì„ì„ ì¶”ì²œí•  ê²ƒì´ë‹¤. For example, if two people watched â€˜Titanicâ€™ and â€˜About Timeâ€™, the model would suggest â€˜About Timeâ€™ for new people who watched â€˜Titanicâ€™

    Loading the dataset

    import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline

    movie_titles_df = pd.read_csv("Movie_Id_Titles")
movie_titles_df.head(20)


    movies_rating_df = pd.read_csv('u.data', sep='\t', names=['user_id', 'item_id', 'rating'])
movies_rating_df.head(10)


    # user_idë¥¼ ê¸°ì¤€ìœ¼ë¡œ ë‘ í…Œì´ë¸” í•©ì¹˜ê¸° merge two tables by 'user_id'
movies_rating_df = pd.merge(movies_rating_df, movie_titles_df, on = 'item_id') 
movies_rating_df


    movies_rating_df.shape

        (100003, 4)

    Data Visualization

    ratings_df_mean = movies_rating_df.groupby('title')['rating'].describe()['mean'] # titleì„ ê¸°ì¤€ìœ¼ë¡œ ratingì„ ì •ë ¬í•œ í‰ê· ê°’ ì €ì¥ saving the average of ratings aligned by 'title'
ratings_df_count = movies_rating_df.groupby('title')['rating'].describe()['count']
ratings_df_count

        title
    'Til There Was You (1997)                                     9.0
    1-900 (1994)                                                  5.0
    101 Dalmatians (1996)                                       109.0
    12 Angry Men (1957)                                         125.0
    187 (1997)                                                   41.0
    2 Days in the Valley (1996)                                  93.0
    20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (1954)                          72.0
    2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)                                259.0
    ...
    Young Poisoner's Handbook, The (1995)                        41.0
    Zeus and Roxanne (1997)                                       6.0
    unknown                                                       9.0
    Ã kÃ¶ldum klaka (Cold Fever) (1994)                            1.0
    Name: count, Length: 1664, dtype: float64

    ratings_mean_count_df = pd.concat([ratings_df_count, ratings_df_mean], axis = 1)
ratings_mean_count_df.reset_index()


    ratings_mean_count_df['mean'].plot(bins=100, kind='hist', color = 'r')

    ìƒê¸° ë¶„í¬ë„ì—ì„œ ë³„ì  í‰ê· ì´ 3ì¸ ê²½ìš°ê°€ ê°€ì¥ ë§ì´ ì°¨ì§€í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì„ í™•ì¸í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤. Star rate 3 appears the most in the distribution above

    ratings_mean_count_df['count'].plot(bins=100, kind='hist', color = 'r')

    ë¶„í¬ë„ì—ì„œ í™•ì¸í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë“¯ì´, ëŒ€ë‹¤ìˆ˜ì˜ ì˜í™”ê°€ ëŒ€ëµ í•œ ë‘ë²ˆ ì •ë„ ì´ë‚´ë¡œ í‰ê°€ë°›ì€ ê²ƒì„ ë³¼ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤. As shown in the distribution, most movies are rated at most two times

    ì•„ì´í…œ ê¸°ë°˜ í˜‘ë ¥ í•„í„°ë§ (item-based collaborative filtering)

    userid_movietitle_matrix = movies_rating_df.pivot_table(index = 'user_id', columns = 'title', values = 'rating')

    ìƒê¸° ì½”ë“œë¡œ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ì§„ í…Œì´ë¸”ì€ ìš”ì†Œê°’ìœ¼ë¡œ â€˜ratingâ€™, ì¦‰ ë³„ì ì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚¸ë‹¤. â€˜ratingâ€™ = star rate

    ì—´ì€ â€˜titleâ€™, ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  í–‰ë“¤ì€ â€˜user_idâ€™ì´ë‹¤. column = â€˜titleâ€™ and row = â€˜user_idâ€™

    titanic = userid_movietitle_matrix['Titanic (1997)']

# Let's calculate the correlations
titanic_correlations = pd.DataFrame(userid_movietitle_matrix.corrwith(titanic), columns=['Correlation'])
titanic_correlations = titanic_correlations.join(ratings_mean_count_df['count'])
titanic_correlations.dropna(inplace=True)

# Let's sort the correlations vector
titanic_correlations.sort_values('Correlation', ascending=False)

    ì˜í™” â€˜íƒ€ì´íƒ€ë‹‰â€™ì´ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì˜í™”ë“¤ê³¼ ì—°ê´€ì„±ì´ ì–¼ë§ˆë§Œí¼ ìˆëŠ”ì§€ Correlation ì—´ì˜ ìš”ì†Œê°’ë“¤ì„ í†µí•˜ì—¬ í™•ì¸ ê°€ëŠ¥í•˜ë‹¤. Can check how much â€˜Titanicâ€™ is related to other movies using Correlation

    titanic_correlations[titanic_correlations['count']>80].sort_values('Correlation',ascending=False).head()

    ê²°ê³¼ í…Œì´ë¸”ì—ì„œ ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” â€˜íƒ€ì´íƒ€ë‹‰â€™ì„ ë³¸ ì‚¬ëŒì—ê²Œ ì¶”ì²œí•´ì¤„ ì˜í™”ë¡œì¨ ê°€ì¥ ì ì ˆí•œ ì˜í™”ëŠ” íƒ€ì´íƒ€ë‹‰ ìê¸°ìì‹ ì„ ì œì™¸í•˜ê³  â€˜River Wild, The (1994)â€™ì¸ ê²ƒì„ í™•ì¸í•œë‹¤. The resultant table tells us the second most appropriate movie for people who watched â€˜Titanicâ€™ is â€˜River Wild, The (1994)â€™

    ê·¸ë ‡ë‹¤ë©´, íƒ€ì´íƒ€ë‹‰ì²˜ëŸ¼ íŠ¹ì • ì˜í™”ì™€ ì—°ê´€ì„±ì´ ë†’ì€ íƒ€ì˜í™”ê°€ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ì „ì²´ ë°ì´í„°ë¥¼ ëŒ€ìƒìœ¼ë¡œ í•œ ë²ˆì— ì—°ê´€ì„±ì„ í™•ì¸í•´ë³¼ ìˆ˜ëŠ” ì—†ì„ê¹Œ? Canâ€™t we check the correlation for all the data at once?

    # Obtain the correlations between all movies in the dataframe
movie_correlations = userid_movietitle_matrix.corr(method = 'pearson', min_periods = 80)

    pearson : standard correlation coefficient

    myRatings = pd.read_csv("My_Ratings.csv")
myRatings


    similar_movies_list = pd.Series()
for i in range(0, 2):
    similar_movie = movie_correlations[myRatings['Movie Name'][i]].dropna() # Get same movies with same ratings
    similar_movie = similar_movie.map(lambda x: x * myRatings['Ratings'][i]) # Scale the similarity by your given ratings
    similar_movies_list = similar_movies_list.append(similar_movie)

    â€˜movie_correlationsâ€™ì˜ ë°ì´í„° ìˆ˜ì¹˜ë“¤ì€ [0, 1] ì‚¬ì´ ê°’ìœ¼ë¡œ, ì„œë¡œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ íƒ€ì´í‹€ ê°„ì˜ ìƒê´€ê´€ê³„ë¥¼ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚´ëŠ” ì§€í‘œì´ë‹¤. â€˜movie_correlationsâ€™ is in range [0, 1] and represents the correlation among titles

    ë”°ë¼ì„œ, â€˜ìƒê´€ê´€ê³„â€™ê°€ ê°€ì¥ í´ ê²½ìš° ê·¸ ê°’ì€ 1ì¼ ê²ƒì´ê³ , ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ ë‹¤ë£¨ëŠ” â€˜ë³„ì â€™ì˜ ì´ì ì€ 5ì ì´ë‹¤. The max corrlation and star rate is 1 and 5, respectively

    ë”°ë¼ì„œ, [0, 1]ì˜ ìƒê´€ê³„ìˆ˜ì— ë³„ì ì„ ê³±í•˜ì—¬, ê·¸ ê°’ì´ ë†’ì€ ìˆœì„œë¡œ ë‚˜ì—´í•œë‹¤ë©´, ê·¸ê²ƒì€ í•´ë‹¹ ì‚¬ìš©ìì—ê²Œ ê°€ì¥ ì•Œë§ì€ ì¶”ì²œ ë¦¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ê°€ ë„ì¶œë  ê²ƒì´ë‹¤. Recommendation systems based on the value of corrlation * star rate

    python similar_movies_list.sort_values(inplace = True, ascending = False) print (similar_movies_list.head(10)) 

        Liar Liar (1997)                             5.000000
    Con Air (1997)                               2.349141

    ìƒê¸° ê²°ê³¼ëŠ” â€˜Liar Liarâ€™ì´ë¼ëŠ” ì˜í™”ì— ë†’ì€ ë³„ì ì„ ì„ ì‚¬í•œ í•´ë‹¹ ì‚¬ìš©ìì—ê²Œ ì¶”ì²œí• ë§Œí•œ íƒ€ì˜í™” ë¦¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì´ë‹¤. Recommending the shown movies for people who watched â€˜Liar Liarâ€™

    ë³„ì ìœ¼ë¡œì¨ í‘œí˜„ëœ ê°€ì¥ ë†’ì€ ì—°ê´€ì„±ì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚´ëŠ” â€˜Liar Liarâ€™ ìê¸°ìì‹ ì„ ì œì™¸í•˜ê³  â€˜Con Airâ€™ë¼ëŠ” ì˜í™”ê°€ ë‘ ë²ˆì§¸ë¡œ í•´ë‹¹ ì‚¬ìš©ìì—ê²Œ ê°€ì¥ ì¶”ì²œí•´ì¤„ ì˜í™”ì¼ ê²ƒì´ë‹¤. The movie â€˜Con Airâ€™ will be the best recommendation for the people.
